valsi.definition: The previous phrase at the same level as -fa is removed and replaced by what follows
valsi.notes: Not for explanatory that~is, for which use |va.

valsi.definition: X1= and following arguments conjoin
valsi.notes: As in the Cartesian expansion of a single argument. Use -tla or -stl to make a set.

valsi.definition: Grammatical level one to three
valsi.notes: /fi gives 1, ^fi gives 2, !fi gives 3.

valsi.definition: Beginning of group
valsi.notes: Not supported in present grammar.

valsi.definition: Event (vo) X1+ is represented by metaphor X2?
valsi.notes: X2 is a sequence of foreign syllables to end of compounding tone. -fn with X2 make a subordinate clause.

valsi.definition: X1 is in the referent set of a foreign word
valsi.notes: The word follows to end of compound tone.

valsi.definition: End of group
valsi.notes: Not supported in present grammar.

valsi.definition: Jump two to four grammatical levels up
valsi.notes: !fu gives 2 up, ^fu gives 3 up, /fu gives 4 up.

valsi.definition: Retroactive downjump: previous argument at same level as fy goes down one level and becomes the first case of the following predicate
valsi.notes: Often used with -tla and -stl for afterthought group arguments.

valsi.definition: X1 is what a foreign word names
valsi.notes: The foreign name follows, to end of compound tone.
The specified case, wherever permuted to by prior conversions, is exchanged with the current first sequential case. The conversion closer to the predicate occurs first.

valsi.definition: Conversion, 3rd case to 1st
Conversion, 4th case to 1st
Conversion, 5th case to 1st
Conversion, 4th case to 2nd
Conversion, 1st case to 3rd
valsi.notes: Resulting order is 2, 3, 1.

valsi.definition: Conversion, 1st case to 1st
valsi.notes: Suppresses any automatic conversion.

valsi.definition: Conversion, 3rd case to 2nd
Conversion, 2nd case to 1st
Conversion, 5th case to 2nd

valsi.notes: The linked argument fills the specified case by number independent of any conversions.

valsi.definition: Caselink, 3rd case
Caselink, 4th case
Caselink, 5th case
Caselink, 1st case
Argument fence
valsi.notes: In an infinitive compound the following infinitive will not eat arguments.

valsi.definition: Caselink, 2nd case

valsi.notes: Prefixes come first in a compound predicate. Sub-phrases may follow any prefix or the complete predicate.

valsi.Engl: Link Words for Clauses and Sentences
valsi.notes: Sentence start prefixes are at the root grammatical level.

valsi.definition: Sentence start, next in sequence or time of occurrence
Sentence start, another item similar to previous sentence
Main sentence start
End of transmission
valsi.notes: Signifies that the speaker will not speak any more.

valsi.definition: Retroactive downjump of sentence
valsi.notes: The previous sentence becomes an infinitive with !vo and becomes the first case of the sentence now beginning

valsi.definition: Start of follow-on sentence with coordinated pronoun referents
valsi.notes: Pronouns and :o respond as if the joined sentences were just one sentence.

valsi.definition: Event (vo) X1+ is represented by metaphor X2?
valsi.notes: X1 is a guaspi phrase, not foreign. -fw with X2 makes a subordinate clause.

valsi.definition: subordinate assertion
valsi.notes: An independent assertion about the restricted sentence or argument. Missing argument defaults to -ji. Use for attitudinals.

valsi.definition: subordinate comment
valsi.notes: A supplementary explanation. Missing argument defaults to -xdro.

valsi.definition: discursive comment
valsi.notes: A subordinate assertion relating restricted phrase to previous discourse. Missing argument defaults to -zgly.

valsi.definition: Event X1: is a member of the referent set of sentence X2?
valsi.notes: To restrict the infinitive rather than the phrase, use -xe |R /vo P

valsi.definition: restrictive subordinate clause
valsi.notes: The restricted relation events must fit this sentence also. Missing argument defaults to -xdro.
Articles specify a subset of the full referent set of the argument. The set may stay a set or may expand into its members.

valsi.definition: X1 is what the following phrase names
valsi.notes: For guaspi predicate names.

valsi.definition: All members of argument's referent subset must fit in parent relation, or sentence is false.
Argument's referent is chosen independently of other instances
Argument's referent is chosen independently of other instances except may not be same as that of the other instances
valsi.notes: Example: -:i !A ^fe -B /(word) !vr -zdmo

valsi.definition: Despite default words this phrase is an argument, not an infinitive
Whole referent set in extension
In-mind elements of referent set, in extension
Typical elements of referent set, in extension
valsi.notes: A few in-mind elements are excluded. On sentence predicate, means 'for the most part'.

valsi.definition: No members of referent set in extension
valsi.notes: Makes negated statement about all referent set members. There is only one null set so it is meaningless to make statements about its members. !xn -jy means 'nothing'.

valsi.definition: Any elements of referent set, in extension
valsi.notes: As in: give me a nail, any one will do. Common with serving-portion words.

valsi.definition: Typical elements of referent set, as set
valsi.notes: A few in-mind elements are excluded.

valsi.definition: Whole referent set, as set
Any elements of referent set, as set
valsi.notes: Example: give me a pair of your dollars; it's not important which ones.

valsi.definition: In-mind elements of referent set, as set
Endmark for quote starting with -be
X1 is an instance of a string to endmark -ba
valsi.notes: The stuffing is considered foreign.

valsi.definition: X1 is an instance of the following phrase X2? as language
valsi.notes: Transforms as an infinitive similar to -vo.

valsi.definition: The referent of the following argument is inserted here
valsi.notes: The referent is supposed to be a text.

valsi.definition: Text X1 has the same referent as the following phrase X2?
valsi.notes: The phrase is an inexact quote meaning about the same as the original. Transforms as an infinitive like -vo.

valsi.definition: X1 is an instance of a delimited string
valsi.notes: The next word is the delimiter; the stuffing, considered foreign, runs until the delimiter recurs.

valsi.definition: X1 is an instance as language of the following words to end of compounding tone
valsi.notes: -bu itself may be quoted; if so, it has no effect.
The following predicate specifies the modal case. Each has a stack on which values can be saved and later restored.

valsi.definition: The modal argument stack for the following predicate is popped
X1 becomes the default modal argument for the following predicate
valsi.notes: The prior default is saved on its stack.

valsi.definition: X1 is the default modal argument for the following predicate
valsi.notes: The previous default is replaced by X1. The previous default is lost.

valsi.definition: The speaker and listener modal cases are exchanged
The modal argument stack for the following predicate has its top two elements interchanged
X1 is the default modal argument for the following predicate
valsi.notes: The default is not changed; the sentence is simply true or false.

valsi.definition: By being uttered the phrase makes something happen
valsi.notes: Example: 'I do' in marriage.

valsi.definition: The phrase is asserted to be real or factual
The phrase is potentially true
valsi.notes: Actual truth is irrelevant

valsi.definition: The phrase is hypothetical
valsi.notes: Reality is irrelevant, and the listener should interpret the words as if the phrase were true (subjunctive mood).

valsi.definition: Central negation
valsi.notes: Makes predicate vanish, e.g. red-gray, above-beside, happy-bored. Also works on central property, e.g. -gl-xbr = slanted, not level.

valsi.definition: This phrase is unreal or counter to fact
valsi.notes: Contradictory negation; the sentence is not true but doesn't say what is true.

valsi.definition: Scale negation
valsi.notes: Makes predicate opposite, e.g. red-cyan, above-below, happy-sad.
A pronoun or a modal default represents words, called its antecedent. Remove the pronoun and substitute the antecedent for it.

valsi.definition: Pronouns: Same Phrase 3rd case
Pronouns: Same Phrase 4th case
Pronouns: Same Phrase 5th case
Pronouns: Same Phrase, the sequentially previous subphrase
Pronouns: Same Phrase 1st case
Pronouns: Same Phrase 2nd case
Pronouns: Same Phrase whole sentence

valsi.notes: The restricted phrase is two levels up from the pronoun, which refers to its other sub-phrases.

valsi.definition: Pronouns: Restricted Phrase 3rd case
Pronouns: Restricted Phrase 4th case
Pronouns: Restricted Phrase 5th case
Pronouns: Restricted Phrase 1st case
Pronouns: Restricted Phrase 2nd case
Pronouns: Restricted Phrase whole sentence
Pronouns: Enclosing Main-Level Sentence, 3rd case
Pronouns: Enclosing Main-Level Sentence, 4th case
Pronouns: Enclosing Main-Level Sentence, 5th case
Pronouns: This and following discourse
valsi.notes: For a title, put xgnl in X1 of xim.

valsi.definition: Pronouns: Enclosing Main-Level Sentence, 1st case
Pronouns: Enclosing Main-Level Sentence, 2nd case
Pronouns: Enclosing Main-Level Sentence, whole sentence
Pronouns: Previous Main-Level Sentence, 3rd case
Pronouns: Previous Main-Level Sentence, 4th case
Pronouns: Previous Main-Level Sentence, 5th case
Pronouns: Previous discourse in general
Pronouns: Previous Main-Level Sentence, 1st case
Pronouns: the event that just happened or that continues to happen now
Pronouns: Previous Main-Level Sentence, 2nd case
Pronouns: Previous Main-Level Sentence, whole sentence

valsi.Engl: Sentence to which Replies are Directed

valsi.definition: Pronouns: Sentence to which Replies are Directed, 3rd case
Pronouns: Sentence to which Replies are Directed, 4th case
Pronouns: Sentence to which Replies are Directed, 5th case
Pronouns: Sentence to which Replies are Directed, 1st case
Pronouns: Sentence to which Replies are Directed, 2nd case
Pronouns: Sentence to which Replies are Directed, whole sentence
(xa) X1M2 we, imperative
valsi.notes: The speaker and the commandee (listener) in an imperative sentence.

valsi.definition: (xa) X1M2 we
valsi.notes: The speaker and the listener.

valsi.definition: X1M2 I, the speaker
Something
valsi.notes: An anonymous variable as in Prolog.

valsi.definition: An alternate object being shown
X1M4 now
valsi.notes: Default for time modal case or present time.

valsi.definition: X1M3 you, imperative
valsi.notes: The commandee, the listener in an imperative sentence.

valsi.definition: X1M5 here
valsi.notes: Default for place modal case or present place.

valsi.definition: X1M3 you, the listener
An object being shown
Something
valsi.notes: The open case of an argument, occuring by default in the first case after conversion.
The listener's reply is supposed to be the pronoun's antecedent.

valsi.definition: Question Pronouns: who or what
valsi.notes: Answer is an argument, the antecedent of the pronoun. Use -py for events (vo).

valsi.definition: Question Pronouns: what is X1:
valsi.notes: Answer is a predicate about the given arguments. Use for events too (vo).

valsi.definition: Question Pronouns: which
valsi.notes: Prefixed to an argument, it asks the listener to designate member(s) from the argument's referent subset.

valsi.definition: Question Pronouns: mood marker
valsi.notes: Answer is typically yes or no.

valsi.definition: Set X1s has how many members X2 in extension
valsi.notes: Answer is a numeric predicate. This is a question pronoun and a quasidigit.
Assign as a name using -xim. Also used as hexadecimal digits 10 to 15 (0.4.1). A hex number must begin with a non-hex digit such as -cy (zero).

valsi.definition: Assignable Variable 3 or digit 13
Assignable Variable 4 or digit 14
Assignable Variable 5 or digit 15
Assignable Variable 1 or digit 11
Assignable Variable 2 or digit 12
Assignable Variable 0 or digit 10

valsi.notes: Assignable variables (0.3.8) are used for hexadecimal digits 10 to 15. A hex number must begin with a non-hex digit such as -cy (zero).

valsi.definition: X1s is a set of 3 members X2, in extension
X1s is a set of 4 members X2, in extension
X1s is a set of 5 members X2, in extension
Negative power of ten follows
X1s is a set of 1 member X2, in extension
X1s is a set of 2 members X2, in extension
X1s IEC a decimal fraction X2, in extension
valsi.notes: Digits: decimal point

valsi.definition: X1s is a set of 0 members X2, in extension
X1s is a set of 8 members X2, in extension
X1s is a set of 9 members X2, in extension
X1s is an equivalence class with a negative number of members X2, in extension
valsi.notes: Normally an unsigned number follows.

valsi.definition: Positive power of ten follows
X1s is a set of 6 members X2, in extension
X1s is a set of 7 members X2, in extension

valsi.notes: These come first in a number.

valsi.definition: X1s is a set with less than N members X2, in extension
valsi.notes: The number follows. Alone: less than one.

valsi.definition: X1s is a set with less than or equal to N members X2, in extension
valsi.notes: The number follows. Alone: at most one.

valsi.definition: X1s is a set with approximately N members X2, in extension
valsi.notes: The number follows. Alone: about one.

valsi.definition: X1s has few members X2, in extesion
valsi.notes: Use -pql for small degree.

valsi.definition: X1s is a set with greater than or equal to N members X2, in extension
valsi.notes: The number follows. Alone: at least one.

valsi.definition: X1s is N'th in list (xy) X2s starting at origin X3
valsi.notes: The number follows.

valsi.definition: X1s is a set with more than N members X2, in extension
valsi.notes: The number follows. Alone: more than one.

valsi.definition: X1s has many members X2, in extension
valsi.notes: Use -fto for great degree.

valsi.definition: (vo) X1+ is N'th in some sequence
valsi.notes: Number follows; it means next if there is no number. Mainly a decoration.
A letteral means X1 is an instance of whatever letter. To spell a word compound the letters; it means X1 is an instance of a word spelled thus.

valsi.definition: X1 is a Roman schwa
valsi.notes: Written as # sign.

valsi.definition: X1 is a Roman glottal stop
valsi.notes: Written as colon.

valsi.definition: X1 is a Roman lower a

X1 is a Greek upper Zeta

valsi.notes: All multi-place predicates are relations, but these are more 'relational' than most.

valsi.definition: X1: is beyond X2: in relation (vo) X3+1,2-4 with reference X4?
valsi.notes: X1 compared to X4 is more than X2-X4. Default X4 is the modal default for X3.

valsi.definition: (xu) X1s is chaotic in property (vo) X2+S1
valsi.notes: X1 is a process or set and its members have property X2.

valsi.definition: X1 is a copy of the original X2*
valsi.notes: Use when the copy and the original can be distinguished.

valsi.definition: In relation (vo) X1+2 all the arguments X2:= repeated as needed, fit equally
valsi.notes: Use -dem to compare math expressions for equality. Use -xim to assign a symbol's value.

valsi.definition: X1 is a recurrent instance of prototype X2*
valsi.notes: X1 automatically has many X2's. Use for non-distinguishable particles in quantum mechanics.

valsi.definition: X1 is a substitute for original X2 in activity or function (vo) X3+1,2
X1: exceeds X2: in quality (vo) X3+1,2
Process (vo) X1@! occurs in the reverse order from process (vo) X2+
X1 is opposite X2* in dimension (xu-vo) X3+1,2
valsi.notes: As in high--low.

valsi.definition: List (xy) X1s is in reverse order from list (xy) X2s*
X1: differs from X2: in dimension (vo) X3+1,2
X1: is similar to X2: in fitting predicate (vo) X3+1,2
Actor X1 compares X2: to X3: on dimension (vo) X4+2,3
Object X1 is like prototype X2 multiplied IEC scale (xu) X3*
valsi.notes: Geometrically similar; same shape but different size. Use -slr =co for congruent.

valsi.definition: Relation (vo) X1+ has arguments X2= repeated as needed
valsi.notes: X2, X3, etc. are in the same referent set member in unspecified cases. No case merge for X1.

valsi.definition: (xy) X1s is a subset of superset (xy) X2s with members (xa) X3*
valsi.notes: Give the defining property in X3; X1 = X2 intersect X3.

valsi.definition: The referents of X1: are the same as the referents of X2:
(xy) X1s is a group with members X2* in extension
valsi.notes: A set of people

valsi.definition: (xy) X1s is a class with members X2*
valsi.notes: A class may be a member of itself while a set may not. See 'Russell's paradox'. Use -diu -sui for learning team.

valsi.definition: X1: is a member of the intersection of set (xy) X2s= repeated as needed
(xy) X1s is a set of members X2* in extension
valsi.notes: Use -tla when each member is given in a separate argument.

valsi.definition: (xy) X1s is a list with members (xu) X2= repeated as needed, in that order
valsi.notes: An ordered set. -xu default because -stl is used for vectors, dates, etc.

valsi.definition: List (xy) X1s is a list of set (xy) X2s in order (vo) X3+PS2,1
X1: is a member of the intersection of (xu) X2:s and the complement of (xu) X3:s
(xa) X1 is one of members X2=? repeated as needed
valsi.notes: Use -xu to get the set.

valsi.definition: (xy) X1s is a system of parts X2 with function (xi-vo) X3+1
valsi.notes: An organized set of parts.

valsi.definition: X1:s is an equivalence class of class (xy) X2s using equivalence relation (vo) X3+P2
X1: is a member of the exclusive union of (xy) X2:s= repeated as needed
valsi.notes: Exclusive or: X1 is in an odd number of argument sets.

valsi.definition: X1: is a member of the intersection of (xy) X2:s= repeated as needed, or of all their complements
X1: is a member of the union of (xy) X2:s= repeated as needed
X1: is a member of the union of (xy) X2:s and the complement of (xy) X3:s
valsi.notes: Use this for a setwise inference.

valsi.definition: X1 is a member of set (xy) X2s*
valsi.notes: Conversion of -sto.

valsi.definition: None of the referents of X1: are referents of X2:*
X1: is a member of the complement set of (xy) X2:s* relative to universal set (xy) X3:s
(xy) X1s is a family with members X2* in extension
valsi.notes: Includes nonhumans.

valsi.definition: (xy) X1s is an orchestra, musical performance group
(xy) X1s is a team for activity (vo) X2+1
valsi.notes: X1 members do X2 collectively. X1 is an organized group.

valsi.definition: (xy) X1s is a committee of organization (xy) X2s with job (vo) X3+1
valsi.notes: X1 is a subset of X2.

valsi.definition: X1s is the boundary of region (xy) X2s* with topology (xy) X3s
valsi.notes: Includes ends of a long object as a set.

valsi.definition: X1 is a part of system X2s*
valsi.notes: X1 is in place or it can be put in and X2 will work.

valsi.definition: (xo) X1 is a mixture of component (xo) X2= repeated as needed
valsi.notes: Like paint; use -sew for overlaps like blue-gray.

valsi.definition: X1 is a piece of system X2s*
valsi.notes: X1 is detached as if broken off.

valsi.definition: X1: occurs only in region X2s*
valsi.notes: Typically X2 is a territory of land; or it can be a set. X1 is typically a thing but can be an event.

valsi.definition: X1 is special among set (xy) X2s in fitting event (vo) X3+1
Set (xy) X1s has few members X2, in extension
X1 is a detail of system (xy) X2s*
X1 is a slice of object X2*
valsi.notes: A (usually) flat piece removed by cutting. X2 is typically food, e.g. a melon or a portion of meat.

valsi.definition: Set (xy) X1s has many members X2, in extension
X1s has parts in set (xu) X2:= repeated as needed
valsi.notes: For red, white and blue flag.

valsi.definition: X1: is most in set (xy) X2s on dimension (vo) X3+S2,1
valsi.notes: Dimension typically is 'importance' but there is no default. Ties for X1 are possible.

valsi.definition: X1: is rare among set (xy) X2s in property (vo) X3+1,S2
valsi.notes: Few X2 members are X3, but X1 is one of them.

valsi.definition: X1: is next in list (xy) X2s* after origin X3
valsi.notes: For lists, processes or oriented objects. First or least member without X3. |pa for N'th from X3 or |tepa for initial segment.

valsi.definition: X1 is previous in list (xy) X2s* before origin X3
valsi.notes: For lists, processes or oriented objects. Tail or largest member without X3. |pa gives N'th from X3 or |tepa for end segment.

valsi.definition: Process X1s ranges over set (xy) X2s*
valsi.notes: Use -xu F for the range of a function.

valsi.definition: X1 is a decoration or adornment on system X2*
X1 is an example member of set (xy) X2s*
valsi.notes: A member of X2 which illustrates clearly what kind of thing is in it.

valsi.definition: X1: meets, encounters X2:*
(vo) X1 is an affair involving persons (xy) X2s*
valsi.notes: Meaning is close to -za -twa = interact.

valsi.definition: X1: is pertinent or relevant to thing X2:*
valsi.notes: For 'possessive' constructions like 'my hat' where X1 = hat, X2 = me. Ownership not required.

valsi.definition: X1: is polite to X2: by action (vo) X3+1
valsi.notes: No automatic replication of X2 into X3.

valsi.definition: X1: has power over person X2 in affair (vo) X3+2
valsi.notes: Typically X3 is something X2 has to do.

valsi.definition: Thinker X1 analyses object X2 with the conclusion (vo) X3+2 from input data (vo) X4+2@
X1 is married to spouse X2
Owner X1 owns property X2*
valsi.notes: Use -zey for ordinary possessive. |gul for the law or |tue for a culture.

valsi.definition: X1 is a friend of X2:
X1 is neutral while participants (xy) X2s have struggle (vo) X3+S2
X1: is at peace with X2:
X1 is an enemy of X2: in affair or struggle (vo) X3+
X1 is interested in subject X2 because it does (vo) X3+2
valsi.notes: Not for rent on money.

valsi.definition: X1: relies on fiduciary X2 to do action (vo) X3+2
Activity (vo) X1+ is done formally
valsi.notes: By standard or expected plans or rules.

valsi.definition: Process (vo) X1 is accidental or random
valsi.notes: Not necessarily bad. Use -psm |stu for bad luck. 'There is no such thing as bad luck.'

valsi.definition: Examinee X1 being/doing test (vo) X3+1@! is a proxy measure for having real quality (vo) X2+1
valsi.notes: |sen for tester, |pyn for interpreter, and |fta for standard. -za -qne means valid.

valsi.definition: Event (vo) X1+ is possible
valsi.notes: Has a low but nonzero probability.

valsi.definition: Event (vo) X1+ is likely
valsi.notes: Has a high probability.

valsi.definition: X1M5 is the location of event (vo) X2+ relative to origin (vo) X3@
valsi.notes: On X2 and X3 do not use -xe even for 'things'; let the default -vo turn things into events.

valsi.definition: X1s is a standard or set of rules by which (vo) X2:+ can be asserted
valsi.notes: Normally X2 IS asserted (use -ge).

valsi.definition: (vo) X1@ is the way or manner in which activity (vo) X2+ is done
valsi.notes: Typically used as an argument; otherwise, just apply the X1 predicate to X2.

valsi.definition: If antecedent (vo) X1@ happens, it is likely that consequence (vo) X2+ also will
Antecedent (vo) X1@ causes consequence (vo) X2+
valsi.notes: Cause is mechanical. Use -kmo for motivation.

valsi.definition: Antecedent (vo) X1@ is a motivation for consequence (vo) X2+
valsi.notes: Buried in X2 is an actor with free will, and X1 induces him to choose to act.

valsi.definition: (vo) X1@ is the purpose for which actor X2 does action (vo) X3+2
Antecedent (vo) X1+ is done because of consequence (vo) X2@
valsi.notes: X2 is a consequence of X1 that motivates someone to do X1 thereby causing X2. Don't state X2 negatively.

valsi.definition: Process X1 proceeds through list of stages (xy) X2s
(vo) X1 is an event having argument X2 in some case
valsi.notes: -zu -qin for argument; -zu -qin |pa for a numbered case.

valsi.definition: (vo) X1 is an error
valsi.notes: |fta for the standard.

valsi.definition: Antecedent (vo) X1@ is a necessary condition for consequence (vo) X2+ to occur
valsi.notes: Use -bni for X1 needs to do X2.

valsi.definition: Antecedent (vo) X1@ is a sufficient condition for consequence (vo) X2+ to occur
Activity (vo) X1+3@ is done under condition (vo) X2+3 by actor X3
Antecedent (vo) X1@ logically entails consequence (vo) X2+
valsi.notes: For definitions and theorems; use -kau for causation. |sya for axioms, |qre for rules of logic.

valsi.definition: X1: is more than usual or expected in dimension (vo) X2+1,S3 for members of set (xy) X3s
valsi.notes: |fta for the standard. -gl -fto means fairly, i.e. at the high end of the usual range.

valsi.definition: X1:! is more than enough for consequence (vo) X2+1@ in dimension (vo) X3+1
valsi.notes: Not necessarily a bad thing.

valsi.definition: X1:! is sufficient for consequence (vo) X2+1@ in dimension (vo) X3+1
X1:! is not quite sufficient for consequence (vo) X2+1@? in dimension (vo) X3+1
valsi.notes: Default X2 is 'to qualify as X3+1', e.g. 'almost cooked'. -gr-jmo means barely.

valsi.definition: X1: is less than usual or expected in dimension (vo) X2+1,S3 for members of set (xy) X3s
valsi.notes: |fta for the standard. -gl -pql means somewhat, i.e. low end of usual range.

valsi.definition: (vo) X1: is accurate
valsi.notes: |pa for how accurate, same units as X1. Use -vju |slr !sa -pa for precision in ratio units. Use -za -qne for valid.

valsi.definition: X1: lacks, has no (xa) X2:*
valsi.notes: Use for objects and servings.

valsi.definition: X1:! is insufficient for consequence (vo) X2+1@ in dimension (vo) X3+1
Set (xy) X1s is regular or uniform in property (vo) X2+S1
valsi.notes: Members of X1 fit X2 to about the same degree. If X1 is not obviously a set, consider its parts.

valsi.definition: Set (xy) X1s is irregular or nonuniform in property (vo) X2+S1
valsi.notes: If X1 is not obviously a set, consider its parts.

valsi.definition: Set (xy) X1s is miscellaneous in property (vo) X2+S1
valsi.notes: Does not fit in obvious groupings by that property.

valsi.definition: X1: IEC the amount, degree or quantity of (vo) X2:+
valsi.notes: For a predicate V for which |pa specifies some amount, -kun -V can recover that amount.

valsi.definition: (vo) X1+2 is a quality that X2: has
valsi.notes: Use -sym or -gre for 'high quality'. Note unusual case merge.

valsi.definition: Part X1 connects to part X2 of system X3
X1: is pertinent or relevant to affair (vo) X2+
(bi) X1 is a problem on the subject (vo) X2!
valsi.notes: A question for students to answer, thereby to learn.

valsi.definition: Object X1 has the status (vo) X2+1
valsi.notes: X2 is a phrase about X1, typically showing its progress in some process or its readiness for operation.

valsi.definition: X1 is a serving/portion of substance (xo) X2*
valsi.notes: Use container word (4.1.1, 4.1.2) to express quantity, or put a unit predicate on the serving.

valsi.definition: All (xy) X1:s members fit the first case of property (vo) X2+S1
valsi.notes: Emphasizing that X2 is a common property of X1 members.

valsi.definition: (vo) X1 occurs
valsi.notes: Or: X1 is an event.

valsi.definition: X1 exists in reality
valsi.notes: |sen for the experiencer. It is very hard to authoritatively assert -stw. Instead assert that you believe it (-cre or -xou) or that it is a fact (-qkr).

valsi.definition: X1: its qualities are represented as a metaphor X2 in dimension (vo) X3+1,2
X1: fits with X2: in relation (vo) X3+1-2
valsi.notes: X3 is a relation between X1 and X2.

valsi.definition: X1 is broken
valsi.notes: In pieces. Use -gr -pwo -sao for 'cannot operate'.

valsi.definition: X1 is open
valsi.notes: Things can go in and out of interior.

valsi.definition: X1 is poisonous to potential victims (xi) X2*
X1 is closed
valsi.notes: Things cannot go in and out of the interior.

valsi.definition: X1 is private to person X2*
valsi.notes: |tue for the culture.

valsi.definition: X1 is wet with liquid (xo) X2*
valsi.notes: Typically water.

valsi.definition: X1 is clear for event (vo) X2+ to happen
valsi.notes: Makes no obstacle. Necessary conditions for X2 about X1, typically being empty, are true.

valsi.definition: X1: is immune to disease or fault (vo) X2+1 due to preventive action (vo) X3+1@!
valsi.notes: For vaccine V, let X3 be -za ^taw -xyn !V (inject V).

valsi.definition: X1 is dead
X1 is perfect
valsi.notes: Has no flaws, cannot be changed to match its standard better. |fta for the standard.

valsi.definition: (vo) X1+ is complete
valsi.notes: |fta for the standard.

valsi.definition: X1: is weak in activity (vo) X2+1
X1: is lazy about activity (vo) X2+1
X1: does activity (vo) X2+1 carefully
X1: is crazy to do activity (vo) X2+1
valsi.notes: |ciw for holder of opinion.

valsi.definition: X1: is clumsy doing activity (vo) X2+1
Actor X1 does activity (vo) X2+1 with difficulty
X1: is faster than usual in activity (vo) X2+1
X1: does activity (vo) X2+1 easily
X1: is slower than usual in activity (vo) X2+1
X1: is wise about affair (vo) X2+1
X1: is foolish to do activity (vo) X2+1
valsi.notes: |ciw for holder of opinion.

valsi.definition: X1: is strong in activity (vo) X2+1
X1: does activity (vo) X2+1 violently
X1: does activity (vo) X2+1 seriously
valsi.notes: Takes extra care, does not give it up. For a serious affair, use -zu -vra.

valsi.definition: X1: does activity (vo) X2+1 gently
X1: is famous for activity (vo) X2+1 among fans (xy) X3s
valsi.notes: -zu -fmu for a famous event.

valsi.definition: X1: hides secret (vo) X2+1 from X3:
valsi.notes: To hide an object, be sure to use -vn to cancel -vo.

valsi.definition: X1: is tired from activity (vo) X2+1
X1 is public
valsi.notes: Accessible to all people. |tue for the culture.

valsi.definition: X1 is precious
valsi.notes: |gae for who feels emotion. A subjective judgement.

valsi.definition: X1 is beautiful
valsi.notes: |ciw for the experiencer.

valsi.definition: X1 is comfortable
valsi.notes: |ciw for experiencer. Example: comfortable bed.

valsi.definition: (vo) X1 is funny
valsi.notes: |gae for experiencer.

valsi.definition: X1 is sane
valsi.notes: |ciw for the one who thinks so.

valsi.definition: (vo) X1 is harmonious
valsi.notes: |ciw for experiencer.

valsi.definition: X1 is delicious
valsi.notes: |ciw for experiencer. In the sense of food.

valsi.definition: X1 is new, novel in aspect (vo) X2+1
valsi.notes: |ciw for the experiencer. Use -ksi for fresh or unused.

valsi.definition: X1 is ordinary in aspect (vo) X2+1
valsi.notes: |ciw for experiencer.

valsi.definition: X1: values X2:*
valsi.notes: X1 has a static, quantitative opinion. Use modal unit to say how much.

valsi.definition: X1 is neat
valsi.notes: Typically a system of neatly organized parts but can be a process. |ciw for holder of opinion. Use -vgn for clean.

valsi.definition: X1 is great, accomplished much in dimension (vo) X2+1
valsi.notes: Being looked up to, accomplishment, not size. |ciw for who holds the opinion, |fta for standard.

valsi.definition: X1 is unimportant in dimension (vo) X2+1
valsi.notes: |ciw for holder of opinion. -vi -zo -fpo means 'by the way'.

valsi.definition: X1 is strange
valsi.notes: Not ordinary. |ciw for experiencer.

valsi.definition: X1 is important in dimension (vo) X2+1
valsi.notes: |ciw for holder of opinion.

valsi.definition: (vo) X1 is sudden
valsi.notes: |sen for experiencer.

valsi.definition: X1 is alien, not a member of the local culture
valsi.notes: |ciw for experiencer (feelings of alienation are not objective).

valsi.definition: X1 is good for purpose (vo) X2+1
valsi.notes: |ciw for holder of opinion.

valsi.definition: X1 is wealthy in kind of wealth (xo) X2*
X1: is tight on or around X2:*
valsi.notes: Not for absence of leaks.

valsi.definition: X1 is evil
valsi.notes: X1 does things that motivate people to hate it (q.v.) |ciw for holder of opinion.

valsi.definition: X1 is poor in kind of wealth (xo) X2*
X1 is bad, unsuitable for purpose (vo) X2+1
valsi.notes: |ciw for holder of opinion. Use |psi for evil.

valsi.definition: X1 is good
valsi.notes: Opposite of evil. |ciw for holder of opinion.

valsi.definition: X1 is brave in danger (vo) X2+1
X1 is a concentrated occupant of territory X2*
valsi.notes: Includes dense population and concentrated solutions.
Use |vrl for a reference frame to interpret horizontal and vertical properties.

valsi.definition: X1 is thin
valsi.notes: Smallest dimension is much smaller than other(s).

valsi.definition: X1 is deep
valsi.notes: Extends far down. Not for 'far from entrance' unless entrance is at the top.

valsi.definition: X1 is narrow
valsi.notes: Horizontal dimension is much less than the other(s).

valsi.definition: X1 is a point of shape X2*
valsi.notes: 'Pointed'. An acute vertex, like the point of a knife.

valsi.definition: X1 is big
valsi.notes: Neutral connotation.

valsi.definition: X1 is thick
valsi.notes: Smallest dimension is large relative to the others.

valsi.definition: X1 is short
valsi.notes: Longest dimension is not very big.

valsi.definition: X1 is small
X1 is broad
valsi.notes: 2nd largest dimension is almost as large as the biggest.

valsi.definition: X1 is bent
valsi.notes: Implies usually straight, or was once straight.

valsi.definition: X1 is shallow
valsi.notes: Extends short way down.

valsi.definition: X1 is long
valsi.notes: Longest dimension is big.

valsi.definition: X1 is sharp
valsi.notes: Vertex or dihedral has a small angle or is not rounded off.

valsi.definition: X1 is large
valsi.notes: Larger than standard or useful. Use -cul -deri to emphasize fat content.

valsi.definition: X1 is light
valsi.notes: Has little mass. Use -xgm for brilliant.

valsi.definition: Container X1 is full of content (xo) X2*
X1 is empty of content (xo) X2*
valsi.notes: X1 is a container that could contain X2 but doesn't.

valsi.definition: X1: is taut over X2:
valsi.notes: For between two points, X2 is a set. Engineering strain is different.

valsi.definition: X1 is simple
valsi.notes: Has few parts or steps.

valsi.definition: X1 is pure
valsi.notes: Meets a high standard (|fta) for impurities included.

valsi.definition: X1 is dense
valsi.notes: For mass density and dense fur. Use -qnr for concentrated.

valsi.definition: X1 is heavy
valsi.notes: Has much mass. Use -vaw for strength, -xgy for stiffness.

valsi.definition: X1 is clean
X1 is expensive for purpose (vo) X2+1
X1 is complicated
valsi.notes: Has many parts or steps.

valsi.definition: X1 is hard
valsi.notes: Resists scratching or cutting. Use -kly for difficult.

valsi.definition: X1 is steep
valsi.notes: At a high angle to the horizontal.

valsi.definition: X1 is under pressure
valsi.notes: |pa for how much. Physical; needs metaphor for emotional pressure.

valsi.definition: (vo) X1 occurs frequently
X1 is loud
valsi.notes: Lots of sound.

valsi.definition: X1 is energetic
valsi.notes: Applies to objects or events.

valsi.definition: X1 is hot
valsi.notes: |pa for actual temperature. Use -zao |qky for hot flavor.

valsi.definition: X1 is quiet
Event (vo) X1 is periodic with period (xu) X2*
X1 is cold
valsi.notes: In temperature. |pa for actual temperature.

valsi.definition: X1 is viscous
X1 sounds like prototype (xi) X2*
valsi.notes: Similar in sound. Not for generalized similarity (-smy).

valsi.definition: X1 is saturated in color
valsi.notes: Use -qnr |tmy for chemical or solution saturation.

valsi.definition: X1 is red
X1 is violet
valsi.notes: A color beyond blue.

valsi.definition: X1 is blue
X1 is brown
X1 is clear or transparent
X1 is gray
X1 is magenta
valsi.notes: Also purple. These are red plus blue.

valsi.definition: X1 is cyan
valsi.notes: This is green plus blue.

valsi.definition: X1 is dark
valsi.notes: Low intensity color or lacks light. Use |sfe for pastel.

valsi.definition: X1 is pastel in color
valsi.notes: The color is low in saturation.

valsi.definition: X1 is white
valsi.notes: A color, not a nationality.

valsi.definition: X1 is blond
valsi.notes: A color special to human hair.

valsi.definition: X1 is orange
X1 is black
valsi.notes: A color, not a nationality.

valsi.definition: X1 is green
X1 is bright
valsi.notes: Brilliant, high intensity color or full of light. Not for 'intelligent' (-kua -swy or similar metaphor).

valsi.definition: X1 is yellow
X1 has a color similar to the color of prototype (xi) X2
valsi.notes: Use -xu -kor for 'the color of X2'.

valsi.definition: X1 looks like prototype (xi) X2*
valsi.notes: Similar in appearance. For general similarity use -smy.

valsi.definition: X1 is soft
X1 is dry
valsi.notes: Lacks liquid.

valsi.definition: X1 is smooth in texture
X1 is elastic or springy
X1 is rough in texture
valsi.notes: Use -vme for violent.

valsi.definition: X1 is stiff
valsi.notes: Resists bending or deformation.

valsi.definition: X1 is malleable
valsi.notes: Shape is easily changed.

valsi.definition: X1 feels like prototype (xi) X2
valsi.notes: Similar in texture. Use -smy for general similarity.

valsi.definition: X1 smells like prototype (xi) X2*
X1 tastes like prototype (xi) X2*
valsi.notes: X2 is a food. Use metaphor, not compound, for (e.g.) hot.

valsi.definition: X1: is here, is at the same place as, has location (jr) X2*M5
valsi.notes: Typically objects but may be events.

valsi.definition: X1 IEC the amount of time that process (vo) X2+ lasts
X1:! IEC a unit of measure for quality (vo) X3+1 times amount (xu) X2
valsi.notes: For foreign units, modify -xnu by metaphor with the foreign name.

valsi.definition: Field X1 is fertile for crop (xo) X2*
X1 is young
X1 is rotten, infested with scavengers (xo) X2*
valsi.notes: X2 are bacterial or metazoan scavengers (maggots).

valsi.definition: X1 is healthy
X1 is fresh
valsi.notes: Undamaged by age or use.

valsi.definition: X1 is relaxed
X1 is sour
valsi.notes: Tastes like acid.

valsi.definition: X1 is bitter in flavor
X1 is old
valsi.notes: Been alive a long time; use -bir for ancient. |pa for how old, low numbers permitted.

valsi.definition: X1 is sweet
X1 is wild
valsi.notes: Not domesticated. Use -gr -dvi for tame.
Often compounded with motion words. Frequently they seem backward to an English speaker, e.g. 'from above' rather than 'downward'.
Use |vrl for a reference frame.

valsi.definition: X1 is below X2:*
valsi.notes: Lower and on a vertical line. Motion from below.

valsi.definition: X1 arches over X2:*
X1 is higher than X2:*
valsi.notes: Geometrically.

valsi.definition: X1 is above X2:*
valsi.notes: Higher and on a vertical line. Movement from above.

valsi.definition: X1 is vertical
X1 is lower than X2:*
valsi.notes: Geometrically.
Use |vrl for a reference frame.

valsi.definition: X1 is north of X2:*
X1 is beside X2:*
valsi.notes: Next in a spatial sequence, usually horizontal and perpendicular to line of sight.

valsi.definition: X1 is in front of X2:*
X1 is in the center of X2s:*
valsi.notes: A central subset (of a set or territory). Use -dyn for center point, -cunu for nucleus.

valsi.definition: X1 is in back of X2:*
X1 is west of X2:*
valsi.notes: Use -jur -sye for turning deasil.

valsi.definition: X1 is south of X2:*
X1 is to the right of X2:*
X1 is to the left of X2:*
X1 is horizontal or level
valsi.notes: Use -fsr for flat.

valsi.definition: X1 is east of X2:*
valsi.notes: -jur -xye for turning widdershins.

valsi.definition: X1: crosses, intersects X2:
valsi.notes: Emphasizes the geometry or fact of intersection. |jir for the intersection point or line.

valsi.definition: X1 is far away from X2:*
(xo) X2* covers X1:
valsi.notes: X2 can be a specific object (needs -xe) or a serving/portion, i.e. blood.

valsi.definition: X2* surrounds X1:
X1: is separate from X2:*?
valsi.notes: Not attached, not part of, though potentially part of X2. With motion words, X2 merges with the start point (3rd case).

valsi.definition: X1 penetrates X2:*
valsi.notes: Statically. -can -pne or -kri -pne for dynamic penetration.

valsi.definition: X1 is in contact with neighbor X2*
valsi.notes: Geometrically. -pwo -kuo for X1 can talk to X2 (in touch).

valsi.definition: X1 is near to neighbor X2*
X1 is between X2: and X3:
valsi.notes: No case merge. Use -juw or -vdr for among.

valsi.definition: X1 is across X2: from X3:
valsi.notes: X2 is a separating zone and X1 is the closest point to X3 on the opposite side.

valsi.definition: X1 is outside of X2:*?
valsi.notes: With motion words, X2 merges with the start point (3rd case).

valsi.definition: X1 is inside of X2:*
valsi.notes: -xu -xyn for the interior of a boundary.

valsi.definition: (vo) X1@! occurs at the same time as, at time (vo-jn) X2+M4
valsi.notes: Present tense.

valsi.definition: (vo) X1@! is before time (vo-jn) X2+M4
valsi.notes: Past tense.

valsi.definition: (vo) X1@! is later than time (vo-jn) X2+M4
valsi.notes: Future tense.

valsi.definition: X1 is oriented in the reverse direction from X2:*
X1 is the direction to destination X2* from origin X3
valsi.notes: The tangent at 0 to a geodesic C(t) such that C(0) = X3, C(1) = X2. X1 is typically a list of components.
See also 0.2.4 for modal default stack controls.
If you do not like to use two explicit infinitives, use -:o.

valsi.definition: Process (vo) X1 occurs in the reverse of its usual order

valsi.notes: Linked with -vi. Some of these words show the speaker's attitude; others show the role of the sentence in the discourse.

valsi.definition: (vo) X1 is a paragraph
valsi.notes: Actually the 1st sentence of a paragraph.

valsi.definition: (vo) X1 is a thesis
valsi.notes: A statement which subsequent discourse will support.

valsi.definition: (vo) X1 is a conclusion
valsi.notes: The statement which prior discourse has demonstrated.
Virtually all activities have an actor in the first case.
In an abstract behavior the activity is given by a separate predicate in an infinitive, usually compounded.

valsi.definition: Actor X1 does action (vo) X2+1
X1 needs to do (vo) X2:+1 so it will have result (vo) X3+1@
valsi.notes: Example: !X1 /bni -byw -kqua = X1 needs to drink water, not needs water.

valsi.definition: X1 changes so property (vo) X2+1 becomes true
valsi.notes: Most of the time use -can, but use -tar to emphasize starting.

valsi.definition: X1 is ordered to do (vo) X2+1 by commander X3
X1 habitually or customarily does (vo) X2:+1
valsi.notes: Use -tue for customs of a culture.

valsi.definition: X1 temporarily is or does (vo) X2:+1
X1 is capable of doing (vo) X2:+1
X1 fails to do (vo) X2:+1
valsi.notes: Implies that the actor tried to do it. Use -gr -poy -gl -qyn for irresponsible negligence.

valsi.definition: Actor X1 makes (vo) X2:+ happen
valsi.notes: Makes transitive meanings. No case merge. Not for building things.

valsi.definition: X1 starts being or doing (vo) X2:+1
valsi.notes: To emphasize the starting; use -can for most changes.

valsi.definition: X1 reverts to have property (vo) X2+1 after a lapse
X1 continuously is or does (vo) X2:+1
X1 stops being or doing (vo) X2:+1
valsi.notes: To emphasize the stopping; use -can or -siw for most changes.

valsi.definition: X1 repeatedly is or does (vo) X2:+1
valsi.notes: Separated by times when it doesn't do it.

valsi.definition: The amount, degree or quantity of property (vo) X1 increases
valsi.notes: Use -gr -kri for decrease.

valsi.definition: X1 ceases to be (vo) X2:+1
valsi.notes: Normal form for a negated change. Use -tiw to emphasize the stopping.

valsi.definition: X1 makes product (xo) X2* by process (vo) X3+1
Actor X1 does action (vo) X2+1
X1 performs the behavior associated with thing X2*
valsi.notes: This word is out of favor. Find a predicate and make a metaphor with X2, e.g. -zou -fw -guna rather than -ban -guna for 'slither'.

valsi.definition: X1 is ready to do (vo) X2:+1
X1 is free to do (vo) X2:+1
X1 succeeds in doing (vo) X2:+1
X1 attempts to do (vo) X2:+1
valsi.notes: No connotation of success or failure.

valsi.definition: X1 does exercise (vo) X2+1 to improve capability or body part X3-1*
X1 responds with behavior (vo) X2+1 to stimulus (vo) X3@
X1 uses means X2 for purpose (vo) X3+1
valsi.notes: Typically X2 is an object and X3 is done by means of X2. In a subordinate clause autoconversion leaves X2 as the 2nd case.

valsi.definition: X1 avoids having (vo) X2:+1 happen
valsi.notes: Example: avoid meeting a person.

valsi.definition: X1 does (vo) X2:+1
valsi.notes: Emphasizes the actor.

valsi.definition: X1 behaves in manner (vo) X2+1 in situation (vo) X3+1@
Victim X1 has event (vo) X2+1 happen to it
X1 is safe from peril (vo) X2:+1
X1 is in danger of having (vo) X2:+1 happen to it
valsi.notes: X2 is the peril.

valsi.definition: X1 waits for (vo) X2:+ before doing action (vo) X3+1@
valsi.notes: X2 compounds, X3 doesn't. X2 lacks case merge, X3 has one.

valsi.definition: X1 survives (vo) X2:+1
X1 tragically has (vo) X2:+1 happen to it
It is lucky that X1: has (vo) X2:+1 happen to it
valsi.notes: X2 is not necessarily an accident.

valsi.definition: X1 gets revenge for (vo) X2:+1 by taking action (vo) X3+1@
valsi.notes: X2 often will have to be converted due to case merge.

valsi.definition: X1 is doomed to be or do (vo) X2:+1
valsi.notes: What fate determines. -xum -can -xtu for doomed to die, the usual English meaning.

valsi.definition: Actor X1 has a certain relation to his action (vo) X2+1
X1 desires to do (vo) X2:+1
X1 has a talent for (vo) X2:+1
X1 intends to do (vo) X2:+1
valsi.notes: Not necessarily actually done.

valsi.definition: X1 is competent in doing (vo) X2:+1
X1 is responsible for (vo) X2:+1 to authority X3
X1 hopes for (vo) X2:+1 to happen
X1 is an authority in/on/over (vo) X2:+1
valsi.notes: Use -per for power, -pew for skill. Authority implies power to act or compel.

valsi.definition: Actor X1 performs action (vo) X2+1 in a certain way
X1 doesn't do (vo) X2:+1 because it is broken
valsi.notes: Use causal connective to say what it does do. -brn for broken in pieces.

valsi.definition: X1 is clowning by doing (vo) X2:+1
X1 performs (vo) X2:+1 manually
valsi.notes: Requiring close human supervision or operation.

valsi.definition: X1 behaves characteristically for a member of set (xu) X2* by doing action (vo) X3+1
valsi.notes: Does not imply that every member of X2 does X3, nor that X1 is in X2.

valsi.definition: X1 does (vo) X2:+1 in obedience to the order or rule (vo) X3+1@ given by authority X4
X1 performs (vo) X2:+1 automatically
valsi.notes: Without the intervention of another controller or actor. Usually a machine but can be a person.

valsi.definition: X1 audaciously does (vo) X2:+1
valsi.notes: X1 relies on a victim's surprise or outrage to get away with X2.

valsi.definition: X1 stubbornly continues to do (vo) X2:+1
X1 plays game (vo) X2:+1
valsi.notes: Use -plu -ziu for playing with an object.

valsi.definition: X1 has fun, is amused by doing (vo) X2:+1
valsi.notes: If amused by an object, X2 is a phrase about what it is/does.

valsi.definition: X1 works on job (vo) X2:+1
Main~actor X1 makes actor X2 do action (vo) X3+2
valsi.notes: See also 2.3.3 Influencing Other People

valsi.definition: X1 is an obstacle keeping X2: from doing (vo) X3:+2
valsi.notes: An obstacle is passive. Hinders but not necessarily prevents.

valsi.definition: X1 helps X2: to do (vo) X3:+2
X1 hinders X2: from doing (vo) X3:+2
valsi.notes: Not necessarily prevents it. X1 acts actively.

valsi.definition: X1 induces X2: to do (vo) X3:+2
X1 forces X2: to do (vo) X3:+2
X1 allows X2: to do (vo) X3:+2
X1 interrupts X2: from doing (vo) X3:+2
valsi.notes: Forces temporary stop.

valsi.definition: X1 commands X2: to do (vo) X3:+2
X1 restrains X2: from doing (vo) X3:+2
valsi.notes: X1 is active and does prevent X3.

valsi.definition: X1 controls X2: in activity (vo) X3:+2
valsi.notes: X2 can be a person or an object.

valsi.definition: X1 demands that X2: do (vo) X3:+2
valsi.notes: Often X1 is the 2nd case of X3, but no automatic merge for this. X3 should be X2 of -gul (rule). X3 is X1's right.

valsi.Engl: Activities by a Pair or Group of Actors
valsi.definition: Competitor X1 and competitor X2 do activity (vo) X3+1,2
X1 competes with X2: in activity (vo) X3+1,2 for prize X4
valsi.notes: In team sports X1 and X2 are teams. In typical races X2 is all the other competitors in extension.

valsi.definition: Team (xy) X1s plays football with team (xy) X2s
valsi.notes: Typically soccer. Use -cor |fw -vanl (olive ball) for American football, per Chinese.

valsi.definition: X1 plays billiards with X2:
X1 fights with X2: about affair (vo) X3+
valsi.notes: No case merge for X3.

valsi.definition: X1 is at war with X2: about affair (vo) X3+
valsi.notes: War is a serious, prolonged and bitter fight.

valsi.definition: X1 flirts with, courts X2:
valsi.notes: Not symmetrical.

valsi.definition: X1 copulates with X2:
valsi.notes: Use -vr (q.v.) to produce a symmetrical meaning.

valsi.definition: X1 kisses X2:
Dancers (xy) X1s dance X2*
valsi.notes: X1 is a set of dancers. X2 is the name or type of the dance.

valsi.definition: All the members of set (xy) X1s do activity (vo) X2+S1 together
X1 wins prize X2 for doing feat (vo) X3+1+4; losers X4
X1 opposes X2: in issue (vo) X3+
X1 interacts with X2: in affair (vo) X3+
valsi.notes: X1 and X2 are typically people.

valsi.definition: X1 argues with X2: about affair (vo) X3+
valsi.notes: No case merge for X3.

valsi.definition: The members of set (xy) X1s discuss affair (vo) X2+
valsi.notes: No case merge.

valsi.definition: X1 talks to listener X2 about affair (vo) X3+
valsi.notes: Let -vo turn objects into events. -kuo is unsymmetrical; -dyw is symmetric.
Often combined with directional properties (1.4.0). They compound with cases X1 and X2. Note the very regular arguments.

valsi.definition: Mover X1 moves to destination X2 from origin X3 via route X4
X1 climbs to X2: from X3: via X4:*
valsi.notes: Climb a tree: the tree is X4. One can climb down too.

valsi.definition: X1 returns to X2: from X3: via X4:
valsi.notes: Implies X1 went from X2 to X3.

valsi.definition: X1 goes to X2: from X3: via X4:
valsi.notes: Emphasizes the change of location.

valsi.definition: X1 moves to X2: from X3: via X4:
valsi.notes: Emphasizes the process of moving rather than the location change or the manner of movement. Use -qkm for 'it moves its legs'.

valsi.definition: X1 falls to X2: from X3: via X4:
X1 swims to X2: from X3: via X4:
X1 jumps to X2: from X3: via X4:
X1 travels to X2: from X3: via X4:
valsi.notes: Going outside of X1's usual territory.

valsi.definition: X1 comes to X2: from X3: via X4:
valsi.notes: Gets nearer the speaker.

valsi.definition: X1 makes a round trip to X2: from X3: and back, via X4:
valsi.notes: X1 ends up at X3.

valsi.definition: X1 runs to X2: from X3: via X4:
valsi.notes: Includes gallop for quadrupeds.

valsi.definition: X1 trots to X2: from X3: via X4:
valsi.notes: Includes the bipedal slow run called jogging.

valsi.definition: X1 walks to X2: from X3: via X4:
valsi.notes: For both bipeds and quadrupeds.

valsi.definition: Mover X1 moves to destination X2 from origin X3 via route X4
X1 canters to X2: from X3: via X4:
X1 swoops to X2: from X3: via X4:
valsi.notes: Use -tal for diving into a pool. Swooper stays airborne.

valsi.definition: X1 flies to X2: from X3: via X4:
valsi.notes: Use -dri -fli for pilot.

valsi.definition: X1 floats to X2: from X3: via X4:*
X1 flows to X2: from X3: via X4:
valsi.notes: Rivers don't flow; the water in them does. Use -zna to get motion word arguments for a river.

valsi.definition: X1 hangs to X2: from support X3*: via X4:
X1* soaks into X2: from X3 via X4
valsi.notes: X2 is often considered the actor.

valsi.definition: X1 turns to angle X2 from X3: around axis X4
valsi.notes: Alternatively, |syo for axis. See -xye, -sye for rotation directions.

valsi.definition: X1 crashes into target X2 from X3: via X4:
X1 drains into X2: from X3: via X4:
valsi.notes: X3 becomes empty, usually by gravity flow.

valsi.definition: X1 spreads over or into X2: from X3: via X4:
valsi.notes: Dynamic, moving.

valsi.definition: X1 slips, slides to X2: from X3: via X4:
X1 rolls to X2: from X3: via X4:
valsi.notes: Moves on wheels, including turning the whole X1.

valsi.definition: Actor X1 makes cargo X2 move to destination X3 from origin X4 via route X5
valsi.notes: Directional properties compound with cases X2 and X3 (mostly).

valsi.definition: X1 excretes excreta X2* into X3: from X4: via X5:
valsi.notes: Also for throwing away trash.

valsi.definition: X1 throws missile X2* to X3: from X4: via X5:
valsi.notes: X1 can be a machine or launcher.

valsi.definition: Driver X1 drives vehicle X2* to X3: from X4: via X5:
valsi.notes: For vehicles and riding animals.

valsi.definition: Guide X1 guides follower X2* to X3: from X4: via X5:
X1 carries cargo X2* to X3: from X4: via X5:
X1 pushes X2* to X3: from X4: via X5:
X1 sends X2* to X3: from X4: via carrier X5
X1 sucks substance X2* into X3: from X4: via X5:
X1 sets, places X2* at or on X3: from X4: via X5:
X1 lifts X2* to X3: from X4: via X5:
valsi.notes: Use -vry -tol for lowering or un-lifting.

valsi.definition: X1 pulls X2* to X3: from X4: via X5:
X1 mails letter X2* to X3: from X4: via X5:
valsi.notes: X5 is typically the carrier.

valsi.definition: Actor X1 makes cargo X2 move to destination X3 from origin X4 via route X5
X1 gathers (xo) X2:* from source X3
valsi.notes: X2 is multi-repeated.

valsi.definition: X1 gets X2:* from custodian X3
valsi.notes: X3 can be a non-active reserve. X1 comes to possess X2 (-kio). Not for begetting.

valsi.definition: X1 gives gift X2* to recipient X3
X1 searches for goal X2* in or at territory X3
X1 hunts, pursues quarry X2*
valsi.notes: Strictly speaking, if X1 is not yet after a specific prey item you should say -xo -gu -X2.

valsi.definition: X1 harvests or reaps crop (xo) X2* from field X3
valsi.notes: X2 is multi-repeated.

valsi.definition: X1 plants X2* at or in field X3
valsi.notes: Putting a plant or seed into soil.

valsi.definition: X1 balances
valsi.notes: Use -tuo or -qmy for the support.

valsi.definition: X1 deflects under load X2*
X1 lays on or in bed X2
valsi.notes: Includes inanimate X1, horizontally oriented. Use -can -fwi for lays down.

valsi.definition: X1 stands on or in X2:
valsi.notes: For animate X1 on its feet, or vertical inanimate X1. Use -can -jan for stands up.

valsi.definition: X1 rests or reposes on bed X2
valsi.notes: For animate X1 that is resting. Use -fwi for recline.

valsi.definition: X1 sits on or in seat X2
valsi.notes: For animate X1 with its thorax vertical. Use -can -duo for sits down.

valsi.definition: X1 stretches to destination X2 from origin X3 via route X4
valsi.notes: Static, not moving over.

valsi.definition: X1 sticks, adheres to substrate X2 by means of glue (xo) X3*
valsi.notes: Insects and seeds also use spines and hooks for X3.

valsi.definition: X1 twists under load X2
X1 explodes into pieces X2
Gymnast X1 does gymnastic feat (vo) X2+1
X1 steps on or in X2
X1 trades places with X2: via route X3
valsi.notes: As decoration, means 'back' as in 'hit him back'.

valsi.definition: Route X1 leads to destination X2 from origin X3 via route X4
valsi.notes: The arguments are the same as for ordinary motion words.

valsi.definition: X1 is a road to X2: from X3: via X4:
X1 is a canal to X2: from X3: via X4:
valsi.notes: Includes natural rivers as routes.

valsi.definition: X1 is a route to X2: from X3: via X4:
valsi.notes: Compounding example: -zur -ze -zou for trail or walkway.

valsi.definition: Speaker X1 says message (bi) X2 to listener X3
X1 shows object X2 to viewer X3
(ji) X1:M2 greets or hails listener (ju) X3M3 with signal (bi) X2
valsi.notes: ^glu alone means hello, while ^gr -glu means goodbye. ^gl -glu is a nice insult.

valsi.definition: (ji) X1M2 quotes (bi) X2:+ to (ju) X3:M3, author X4
valsi.notes: Saying a text exactly as written. When -kuw is the main predicate of a sentence you may need !vn -X2 to suppress default -bi.

valsi.definition: (ji) X1M2 explains event (vo) X2+ to (ju) X3:M3
(ji) X1M2 gives answer (bi) X2+ to question (bi) X3@ speaking to (ju) X4:M2
(ji) X1M2 asks question (bi) X2+ of (ju) X3:M3
(ji) X1M2 says (bi) X2:+ to (ju) X3:M3
valsi.notes: Modal case for speaker, and listener in dialog.

valsi.definition: (ji) X1M2 cries (bi) X2:+ to listener (ju) X3M3
valsi.notes: Emotional upset, often but not necessarily loud. Use -jai |kqe for shout.

valsi.definition: (ji) X1M2 says (bi) X2: emphatically to (ju) X3:M3
valsi.notes: The written equivalent of loud or otherwise forceful speech.

valsi.definition: X1 utters (bi) X2:+ in language X3
valsi.notes: Focus on linguistic aspect.

valsi.definition: Performer X1 performs art X2
X1M2 sings song X2 for audience (xy) X3sM3
X1 performs work of art X2 for audience (xy) X3s
X1 writes message (bi) X2+ on media X3
X1 prints message (bi) X2+ on media X3
valsi.notes: Using a machine rather than handwriting.

valsi.definition: X1 whistles music X2
(ji) X1M2 thinks thought (bi) X2+ to listener (zdmo) X3M3
valsi.notes: Alternative modal case for speaker. Except for psychic X1, X3 always defaults to copy X1.

valsi.definition: Speaker X1 tells listener X2 about event (vo) X3+
valsi.notes: No case merge for X3.

valsi.definition: X1 publicizes (vo) X3:+ to audience X2
valsi.notes: No case merge in case of self-promotion. Note different case order from English.

valsi.definition: X1 requests to get thing X2 from custodian X3
valsi.notes: Use -ciu to ask that X2 do something.

valsi.definition: X1M2 suggests to (ju) X2:M3 that it do (vo) X3:+2
X1 deceives X2: about (vo) X3:+1
X1M2 warns (ju) X2:M3 about (vo) X3:+2
valsi.notes: !xe X3 for an object, but a phrase is preferred for X3, e.g. -zu -crw !kqeo 'being eaten by the lion' rather than just 'the lion'.

valsi.definition: X1M2 promises to (ju) X2:M3 that it will do (vo) X3:+1
valsi.notes: X1 may or may not actually do it. No case merge for X2.

valsi.definition: X1 is honest with X2: about (vo) X3:+1
X1 says that relation (vo) X2+ is true
X1M2 protests to (ju) X2:M3 about (vo) X3:+2
X1 consents to do action (vo) X2+1 per requester X3
valsi.notes: -tuw -juy if someone other than X1 will do it.

valsi.definition: X1M2 requests that (ju) X2:M3 do (vo) X3:+2
X1 agrees with X2: that fact (vo) X3+ is true
valsi.notes: No case merge. X2 is the primary holder of the opinion.

valsi.definition: X1 teaches student X2 to do skill (vo) X3+2
X1 curses victim X2 to have (vo) X3:+2 happen by words or ritual (bi) X4@
valsi.notes: Explicit !vo required for ritual. A curse is usually bad for X2.

valsi.definition: Experiencer X1 has a feeling about actor X2 doing event (vo) X3+2
X1 ridicules X2: for doing (vo) X3:+2
valsi.notes: Use -cau =smi -qyw (ridicule wise behavior) for mock.

valsi.definition: X1 laughs at event (vo) X2+
valsi.notes: Laugh at a person: let -vo turn objects into events.

valsi.definition: X1 frowns at event (vo) X2+
valsi.notes: Frown at a person: let -vo turn objects into events.

valsi.definition: X1 smiles at event (vo) X2+
valsi.notes: Smile at a person: let -vo turn objects into events.

valsi.definition: X1 is annoyed that X2: does (vo) X3:+2
valsi.notes: No automatic merge for X1.

valsi.definition: (ji) X1 feels pleased that X2: does (vo) X3:+2
valsi.notes: For English decoration 'please' on imperatives.

valsi.definition: Thinker X1 thinks that object X2* has property (vo) X3+2 because of input data (vo) X4+2@
X1 deduces that X2: is (vo) X3:+2 from input data (vo) X4+2@
valsi.notes: There exists a logic (-sny, q.v.) from X4 to X3, which X1 discovers.

valsi.definition: X1 decides that X2: is (vo) X3:+2 from input data (vo) X4+2@
X1 remembers that X2: is (vo) X3:+2 prompted by input data (vo) X4+2@
X1 judges that X2: is (vo) X3:+2 from input data (vo) X4+2@
valsi.notes: Authoritative determination, not estimation, but not necessarily in court.

valsi.definition: X1 infers that X2: is (vo) X3:+2 from fact (vo) X4+2@
valsi.notes: Compared to the logic (-sny, q.v.) of a deduction, inferential reasoning is based more on experience and probability.

valsi.definition: X1 estimates that X2: is (vo) X3:+2 from input data (vo) X4+2@
valsi.notes: Generally X3 is quantitative.

valsi.definition: X1 intuits that X2: is (vo) X3:+2 from input data (vo) X4+2@
valsi.notes: Intuition. The logic (-sny, q.v.), if any, from X4 to X3 is found only afterwards, if at all.

valsi.definition: X1 learns to do skill (xo-vo) X2+1 from teacher X3
X1 thinks about affair (vo) X2+
X1 discovers that X2: is (vo) X3:+2 from input data (vo) X4+2@
Thinker X1 knows that object X2* has property (vo) X3+2
X1 believes that X2: is (vo) X3:+2
X1 doubts that X2: is (vo) X3:+2
X1 is certain that X2: is (vo) X3:+2
X1 is confused about X2: its property (vo) X3+2
X1 is curious about X2: its property (vo) X3+2
X1 holds the opinion that X2: is (vo) X3:+2
It seems to X1: that X2: is (vo) X3:+2
valsi.notes: X1's information says so, but may or may not be true.

valsi.definition: X1 understands that X2: is (vo) X3:+2
X1 knows that X2: is (vo) X3:+2
X1 guesses that X2: is (vo) X3:+2
valsi.notes: An English guess is an answer; in guaspi it is an opinion: static. There is not enough information to be sure of it.

valsi.definition: X1 feels that subjective opinion (vo) X2+ is true
valsi.notes: Modal case for the holder of a subjective opinion.

valsi.definition: Experiencer X1 perceives event (vo) X2+
X1M3 is a spectator or member of the audience at event (vo) X2+3 performer X3M2
X1M3 dreams event (vo) X2+3 done by (zdmo) X3:M2
X1 is conscious or aware of (vo) X2:+
X1 reads text X2
valsi.notes: The referent of X2 should be a text. If the text has a title, that may appear (as a name) in X2.

valsi.definition: X1 looks at object X2
valsi.notes: By eyeball. Use -qnu, -kur, -den for various kinds of paying attention.

valsi.definition: X1 pays attention to event (vo) X2+
valsi.notes: Use -qnu for data attended to.

valsi.definition: X1 perceives event (vo) X2+1
X1 watches actor X2 do event (vo) X3+2
X1 hears sound (vo) X2+ against background (vo) X3@
X1 sees object X2 against background X3
X1M3 attends to information (bi) X2+ from source or speaker X3M2
valsi.notes: Modal case for listener. -qnu is said by speaker; in dialog the narrator uses |jai !sa X instead.

valsi.definition: X1 senses stimulus (vo) X2+
valsi.notes: Modal case for experiencer of more-or-less objective sensations. X2 includes mental states like -psw (ordinary).
Transitive means an actor does something to an object. Most predicates are not transitive. Use -qma to make them so.

valsi.definition: Actor X1 does some life activity
X1 breathes air (xo) X2
valsi.notes: X2 can be another breathing gas, or water in drowning.

valsi.definition: X1 is awake
X1 digests food X2*
X1 hungers to do activity (vo) X2+1
valsi.notes: Feels a strong physiological drive. Needs -jie -crw for hungers to eat.

valsi.definition: X1 sleeps
X1 relaxes itself by doing activity (vo) X2+1
valsi.notes: X1 is usually a person.

valsi.definition: X1 coughs up sputum (xo) X2
X1 wears out by itself
X1 sneezes
X1 is alive
X1 vomits substance (xo) X2* on target X3 from origin X4 via route X5
X1 weeps tears (xo) X2 because event (vo) X3+1 happens
Producer X1 makes product X2
X1 gives birth to baby X2
X1 sews part X2 onto clothes X3
valsi.notes: Attaches X2 by sewing, or joins similar-sized X2 and X3.

valsi.definition: X1 weaves cloth X2 from thread (xo) X3
valsi.notes: X3 is the type of thread used, e.g. wool.

valsi.definition: X1 invents apparatus X2 that performs function (vo) X3+2
X1 organizes parts (xy) X2s into system X3s
X1 makes X2:* out of material (xo) X3
valsi.notes: X2 should be a unitary object, not a system, for which use -smu. -qma for transitive make.

valsi.definition: X1 builds or assembles system X2s by adding parts X3
valsi.notes: Use -dma for a unitary object.

valsi.definition: X1 cooks food X2* for eater X3
valsi.notes: Usually involves heat but includes preparing wholly cold food.

valsi.definition: X1 is an architect or designer of (xi) X2:*
valsi.notes: Explicit !xe needed to say X1 designed a specific X2.

valsi.definition: Actor X1 uses up object X2* making pieces X3
X1 drinks beverage (xo) X2* out of vessel X3
X1 cuts X2: into pieces (xo) X3
X1 wastes (xo) X2:* on activity (vo) X3+1
X1 grinds X2: into powder (xo) X3
X1 smashes, squishes X2:* into a pulp (xo) X3
X1 destroys X2:*
X1 uses up (xo) X2:* on activity (vo) X3+1
valsi.notes: Not implying waste.

valsi.definition: X1 crushes, crunches X2:* into pieces (xo) X3
X1 tears X2: into shreds (xo) X3
X1 scrapes X2:* dislodging shavings (xo) X3
X1 eats food X2*
Actor X1 uses object X2* in relation to object X3
X1 distributes goods (xo) X2 to or among the members of set (xy) X3s
valsi.notes: X2 is often servings but can be a set whose members are distributed.

valsi.definition: X1 fills vessel X2 with content (xo) X3*
X1 bathes in liquid (xo) X2*
valsi.notes: X2 is the bathwater; use -xyn or -vel for a bathtub.

valsi.definition: X1 rubs X2: with X3:
X1 touches X2: with X3:
X1 washes X2: in liquid (xo) X3
valsi.notes: X3 is the bathwater; use |xyn or |vel for a bathtub.

valsi.definition: X1 holds X2: with its body part X3-1
valsi.notes: Not for the hold of a ship.

valsi.definition: Share X1 pertains to recipient X2 of goods (xo) X3* being distributed among set (xy) X4s
X1 selects member X2* from set (xy) X3s
X1 measures object X2 in quality (vo) X3+2
valsi.notes: Use |pa or |kun for the result.

valsi.definition: X1 sells X2:* to buyer X3 for price X4
valsi.notes: Use -dia for non-money trade. Use -za -ven for buy.

valsi.definition: Actor X1 makes object X2* be or do event (vo) X3+2
X1 protects X2: from (vo) X3:+2
valsi.notes: X1 can be an actor or an artifact e.g. paint.

valsi.definition: X1 folds X2:*
valsi.notes: |pa for how many times. Not for a corral.

valsi.definition: X1 fixes, repairs X2: its fault (vo) X3+2
X1 adjusts X2: in its function (vo) X3+2
Custodian X1 takes care of X2:
X1 serves client X2 by doing (vo) X3:+1
valsi.notes: Use -gey or -gey -fw -sru for serving food.

valsi.definition: X1 stirs X2:*
valsi.notes: |tum for the tool.

valsi.definition: X1 rewards actor X2 for doing (vo) X3:+2 with reward X4
X1 is kind to beneficiary X2 by doing (vo) X3:+1
valsi.notes: No automatic X2 merge.

valsi.definition: X1 shelters (xo) X2:* from (vo) X3:+2
valsi.notes: X1 can be an actor or an artifact e.g. a house; xo is there for compounds like -qel -fkar = garage.

valsi.definition: X1 supports X2:
valsi.notes: Primary meaning is mechanical; make good metaphors for secondary meanings.

valsi.definition: X1 translates text X2 to language X3 from language X4
valsi.notes: X2 may be 'someone's speech'.

valsi.definition: X1 treats patient X2 for disease (vo) X3+2 with medicine X4
valsi.notes: Not for Ph.D.

valsi.definition: Actor X1 harms victim X2* by doing event (vo) X3+1
X1 bites X2: on its body part X3-2
X1 hits X2: with weapon X3* on its body part X4-2
valsi.notes: X3 can also be a body part of X1.

valsi.definition: X1 stabs X2: with knife X3* in body part X4-2
X1 attacks X2: to get goal (vo) X3+
valsi.notes: No case merge.

valsi.definition: X1 is harsh to X2: by doing (vo) X3:+1
valsi.notes: No case merge for X2.

valsi.definition: X1 takes object X2 away from former owner X3
X1 is cruel to X2: by doing (vo) X3:+1
valsi.notes: No merge of X2 into X3.

valsi.definition: X1 kicks X2: on its body part X3-2
X1 punishes X2: for doing (vo) X3:+2@! with punishment (vo) X4+2
valsi.notes: X4 must often be converted due to case merge.

valsi.definition: X1 hurts X2: by doing (vo) X3:+1
valsi.notes: No automatic merge for X2.

valsi.definition: X1 makes trouble for X2: by doing (vo) X3:+1
X1 holds prisoner X2 in prison X3
Active~object X1 performs some activity
X1 breaks by itself into pieces X2
X1 vibrates
valsi.notes: So fast you can't see.

valsi.definition: X1 radiates rays (xo) X2*
valsi.notes: Many emitted substances (light, sound, smoke) have a case for the source.

valsi.definition: X1 shakes or oscillates
valsi.notes: Use -sur for repetitive events.

valsi.definition: X1 operates performing function (vo) X2+1
X1 boils
valsi.notes: Turns to vapor.

valsi.definition: X1 makes a hissing sound
X1 burns
Actor X1 does some activity
X1 develops or matures to become adult (vo) X2+1
valsi.notes: Use -jaw for getting bigger.

valsi.definition: X1 digs up object X2 out of soil X3
X1 grows to become (vo) X2+1

valsi.notes: X1 is a list of (xu) numbers, largest first. X2 auto-converts. X3 compounds. Hour: -tem -qrau

valsi.definition: (vo) X1 is a religious belief or practice of people (xy) X2s*
X1 practices art (xo-vo) X2+1
valsi.notes: The art of doing some activity.

valsi.definition: X1 is sacred to people (xy) X2s*
valsi.notes: Usually an object or place; use -jil for activity.

valsi.definition: X1 is a model of real object (xo) X2*
valsi.notes: A metaphoric object, usually small, showing only essential features.

valsi.definition: X1 is a toy representing real objct (xo) X2*
valsi.notes: A metaphoric object used for playing.

valsi.definition: X1 is an idea about affair (vo) X2+
X1 is an industrial art for making goods (xi) X2*
valsi.notes: |tue for culture.

valsi.definition: X1 is a language of culture X2
X1 is a vocal signal of creature X2*
(bu) X1 is a word of language X2 with meaning X3
valsi.notes: X3's referent set suggests what '-xe X1' would produce if it were guaspi --- training aid only.

valsi.definition: X1 is a grammar of language X2
Word (bi) X1@ rhymes with word (bi) X2
X1 is an article
valsi.notes: Prefix which selects referent subset.

valsi.definition: X1 is a consonant phoneme
X1 is a vowel phoneme
(bu) X1 is a predicate word of guaspi with meaning X2
valsi.notes: X2's referent set suggests what '-xe X1' would produce --- training aid only.

valsi.definition: X1 is the first case of relation (vo) X2+
valsi.notes: Convert X2 for N'th case. Use -qin for case occupant or actual argument.

valsi.definition: X1 is a pronoun
X1 is a letter of alphabet X2
valsi.notes: Of the alphabet that goes with language X2.

valsi.definition: (bi) X1 is a restrictive phrase
X1 is the tone of word (bu) X2
(bi) X1 is an assertion
X1 is the modal case of relation (vo) X2@! on dimension (vo) X3+
valsi.notes: -qin |dlmo for actual argument. X3 is the modal predicate and X1 is its 2nd case after autoconversion.

valsi.definition: X1 is a mood prefix word
(bi) X1 is a phrase of language X2*
valsi.notes: X2 typically is guaspi. Use -sym -zdua for main or discourse-level sentence.

valsi.definition: X1 is in the referent set of word (bi) X2
valsi.notes: Use !xu to get the whole set.
A unit is a function that multiplies an expression by a basis element giving the class of events that big on the relevant dimension.

valsi.definition: X1: is in the equivalence class of value (xu) X2
X1 IEC (xu) X2:* seconds
valsi.notes: SI basis unit of time.

valsi.definition: X1 IEC (xu) X2:* years
X1 IEC (xu) X2:* hours
X1 IEC (xu) X2:* months
X1 IEC (xu) X2:* minutes
X1 IEC (xu) X2:* days
X1 IEC (xu) X2:* weeks
X1: is in the equivalence class of value (xu) X2
X1 IEC (xu) X2:* times one radian of angle
valsi.notes: 1/2pi of a circle.

valsi.definition: X1 IEC value (xu) X3 times the capacity of container (xi) X2*
valsi.notes: As in spoonful.

valsi.definition: X1 IEC (xu) X2:* moles
valsi.notes: CGS and (apparently) SI basis unit of amount of material, 6.02E23 atoms or molecules.

valsi.definition: X1 IEC (xu) X2:* degrees Kelvin
valsi.notes: SI basis unit of temperature.

valsi.definition: X1 IEC (xu) X2:* candela
valsi.notes: SI basis unit of luminosity.

valsi.definition: X1 IEC (xu) X2:* kilograms
valsi.notes: SI basis unit of mass. Not compound (kilo-gram) in guaspi.

valsi.definition: X1 IEC (xu) X2:* times one steradian of solid angle
valsi.notes: 1/4pi of a sphere.

valsi.definition: X1 IEC (xu) X2:* times one degree of angle
valsi.notes: 1/360 of a circle.

valsi.definition: X1 IEC (xu) X2:* meter
valsi.notes: SI basis unit of length.

valsi.definition: X1 IEC (xu) X2:* grams
valsi.notes: CGS basis unit for mass.

valsi.definition: X1 IEC (xu) X2:* basis money units of culture X3
valsi.notes: You may attach the native money word by metaphor.

valsi.definition: X1 is a child of parent X2
valsi.notes: Human only.

valsi.definition: X1 is a male human
X1 is a female of species X2*
X1 is a girl of parents X2
valsi.notes: Female human child.

valsi.definition: X1 is a person
valsi.notes: Not necessarily human.

valsi.definition: X1 is a female human
X1 is a male of species X2*
X1 is a human
X1 is a boy of parents X2
valsi.notes: Male human child.

valsi.definition: X1 is an adult
valsi.notes: Any species.

valsi.definition: X1 is a baby of parents X2
valsi.notes: Any species.

valsi.definition: X1 is a fetus of parents X2
valsi.notes: Any species.
Of all areas where guaspi is culturally biased, the family relations are the most blatant.

valsi.definition: Male X1: is the son of parents X2
valsi.notes: X2 is any sex, may include both parents.

valsi.definition: Male X1: is the father of offspring X2 by female mother X3
Male X1: is a brother of sibling X2 by parents X3
Female X1: is the mother of offspring X2 by male father X3
X1: is a sibling of X2: by parents X3
Female X1: is a sister of sibling X2 by parents X3
Female X1: is a daughter of parents X2
valsi.notes: X2 is any sex, may include both parents.

valsi.definition: X1 is a warrior of nation X2
X1 is a secretary of bureaucrat X2
X1 is a soldier of nation X2
valsi.notes: Land warrior.

valsi.definition: X1 is a student at school X2 studying skill (xo-vo) X3+1
X1 is a policeman of organization X2
valsi.notes: X2 is the unit protected, e.g. city, state. Includes private security forces.

valsi.definition: X1 is a diplomat of nation X2 in place X3
X1 is a deputy to chief X2*
valsi.notes: X1 has X2's authority when X2 isn't there.

valsi.definition: X1 is the captain of team or crew (xy) X2s
valsi.notes: Includes ship captains.

valsi.definition: X1 is an assistant to chief X2*
valsi.notes: X1 cannot do X2's job alone.

valsi.definition: X1 is a god responsible for function (vo) X2+1
valsi.notes: |tue for the culture.

valsi.definition: Rule (bi) X1@ requires behavior (vo) X2+ in moral system or religion X3
valsi.notes: X2 includes obligee.

valsi.definition: X1 is entitled to do activity (vo) X2+1 because of rule (vo) X3+@
Actor X1 must do activity (vo) X2+1 by rule (bi) X3@ promulgated by authority X4
valsi.notes: Use -qre for scientific rules.

valsi.definition: X1 is the local culture containing people (xu) X2
valsi.notes: The usual self-referential word: only -xa -zu -spi are people!

valsi.definition: (vo) X1 is a tradition of culture X2
X1 is a culture supported by people X2 consisting of behaviors (vo) X3+2
X1 insures client X2 against peril (vo) X3+2 for premium (xu) X4
valsi.notes: X2 pays X4 to X1. X4 is usually money per time.

valsi.definition: X1 is a company for activity (vo) X2+1 chartered by authority X3
X1 trades goods X2* with other trader X3 in exchange for goods X4
valsi.notes: For barter; use -ven for selling for money.

valsi.definition: X1 offers goods X2 to buyer X3 for price or exchange X4
valsi.notes: Also use for non-exchange offers, e.g. 'he offered her some grapes'.

valsi.definition: X1 is a coin or bill IEC denomination (xu) X2 issued by government X3
valsi.notes: Use -cenu -tlme for coin, -cenu -crar for bill.

valsi.definition: X1 owes money (xu) X2 to lender X3 for or secured by asset X4
valsi.notes: X2 is typically money but doesn't have to be.

valsi.definition: X1 lends goods X2 to borrower X3 for IEC rent (xu) X4
valsi.notes: Includes renting, and no-fee lending. If X2 is repeated (e.g. money), X4 is money per X2 unit, usually also per time.

valsi.definition: X1 earns wages (xu) X2 for work (vo) X3+1
X1 gives amount of credit (xu) X3 to borrower X2 for interest (xu) X4
valsi.notes: Credit is a potential money loan.

valsi.definition: X1 is the profit to entrepreneur X2 from transaction (vo) X3
valsi.notes: No case merge or compounding for X3.

valsi.definition: X1 IEC the price of goods X2* to buyer X3
valsi.notes: Needs explicit -vo X2 for a service.

valsi.definition: X1 gives payment (xu) X2 to vendor X3 for goods or services X4
X1 has a legal obligation to do activity (vo) X2+1
valsi.notes: |gul for the rule and the authority or agency.

valsi.definition: X1 is a nation or state with citizens (xy) X2s
X1 is an army of nation X2
X1 is taxed for activity (vo) X2+1 by agency X3 at rate (xu) X4
valsi.notes: For tax on things: X2 is -ziu X or -bou X. |pa for the amount.

valsi.definition: (vo) X1+ is a crime
valsi.notes: |gul for the law, |tue for the culture.
